Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Understanding Traffic Dynamics in Cellular Data Networks and Applications to Resource Management

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Broadband cellular networks are emerging to be the most common means for mobile data access worldwide. Predictions from industry analysts indicate that the volume of data through cellular data networks will increase exponentially in near future. Understanding of the mobile data traffic via measurement and analysis is critical for the development of resource management techniques for these networks. While spectrum resources are of great concern, this project specifically focuses on the ?energy? required to operate the cellular network infrastructure, specifically base stations. The project undertakes a significant modeling exercise with two goals. One goal is ?intellectual,? driven towards understanding the spatio-temporal dynamics of mobile traffic and discovering possible structure or relationships. The project uses state-of-the-art machine learning tools to develop models using large-scale data collected directly from the operators? networks. Such modeling will bring new insights that in turn will help to deploy and manage future generation cellular data networks. The second goal is ?utilitarian.? Here, techniques are developed to predict base station loads for use in resource management, specifically energy. Algorithms are designed to exploit energy-optimization opportunities to turn off specific network resources based on the forecasted load.

The project has significant broader impact. It develops technologies to appreciably reduce energy consumption in cellular networks. Overall, this exercise will both reduce cost, and contribute to the environment. The project also contributes to several 'green? initiatives in both institutions and to the education and training of graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project demonstrated how analytics on mobile network traffic data can be gainfully employed for better mobile network design. We have used data collected at the backbone of major cellular providers to showcase how to perform better scheduling to reduce traffic congestion, better energy management at the cellular towers and better traffic estimation without significant measurement infrastructure. We also developed techniques for network data pricing and better mechansims to localize cellular device from the provider's network. Finally, we analyzed performance of several mobile virtual network operators and developed new resource management techniques for future virtualized mobile network packet core. We project also indirectly contributed to several spectrum management studies that we are pursuing in complementary projects. 

Part of the above work used state of the art machine learning techniques such as structure learning and semi-supervised methods for network data analysis that provided much improved results relative to known techniques. 

Regarding broader impact, the project contributed to the research training of a number of graduate students. Four PhD students involved in the project graduated with thesis topics in related areas and got employment in top technology companies in US. The project resulted in technology transfer to Bell Labs (joint patent) and several interactions with telecom companies and labs, including Bells Labs, AT&T and Huawei. The project also contributed to several learning tools in a graduate course on wireless networking in Stony Brook University.
